question.query: analyze the crypto agent market - which protocols are gaining traction and why

steps.text:
Short answer
- The agent/automation layer is maturing fast. Protocols gaining the most real traction right now are: Chainlink Automation (on‑chain scheduling/keepers), Gelato (automation + agent frameworks/plugins), dedicated “agent platforms/marketplaces” (Autonolas / Olas and similar projects), agent SDKs/OS projects (StateSet, Cortex, Open AEA / Open Autonomy), and decentralized AI / compute/data stacks that enable agents (Fetch.ai, Render, Ocean, Bittensor).  
- Why: broad developer integrations, robust execution guarantees (oracles/relayers), token/incentive models and marketplaces for agents, standards work (discovery/trust), plus integrations with LLMs/compute. See sources at the end.

Deeper analysis

1) Categories to watch (and the leading names)
- On‑chain automation / reliable execution
  - Chainlink Automation (Keepers → Automation, OCR3, CRE): high reliability, multi‑chain support, widely used for recurring jobs and triggers. Developers migrate existing upkeeps to newer registries and Chainlink continues to add tooling (Chainlink Runtime Environment). Evidence: Chainlink docs and migration notices.  
  - Gelato Network: general-purpose automation, growing plugins for AI agents (ElizaOS / Gelato plugin). Gelato is used for task execution, gas-relays and agent-triggered transactions across EVM chains.

- Agent marketplaces, ownership & coordination layers
  - Autonolas / Olas (OLAS): projects explicitly building an “agent economy” with agent registries, marketplaces and token coordination (agent app stores, mech marketplaces). Olas/Autonolas public docs and blogs highlight millions of agent-to-agent transactions and marketplace features.
  - Other marketplace-ish entrants: Autonomys, Virtuals/DIRA and similar projects that package agents as composable, monetizable units.

- Agent SDKs / Agent OS (developer tooling)
  - Open Autonomy / Open AEA (Autonolas), StateSet (Agentic OS), Cortex Agent Platform: frameworks for building multi‑agent systems, composition, and secure off‑chain/on‑chain coordination. These are important because developer productivity (SDKs, templates, secure coordination) is a leading adoption driver.

- Decentralized AI compute / data & model marketplaces (enabling infrastructure)
  - Fetch.ai (autonomous economic agents, own chain/Cosmos SDK), Render Network, Ocean Protocol, Bittensor: provide data, inference/compute or agent execution infrastructure so agents can run useful tasks without relying solely on centralized clouds.

- Standards & primitives
  - ERC‑8004 (Trustless Agents standard, published/announced Aug 2025): attempts to codify agent discovery, capability advertisement, identity/reputation primitives. Standards accelerate interoperability and marketplace liquidity.

2) Why these protocols are winning adoption (the main drivers)
- Reliability & execution guarantees: agents must execute on chain or trigger transactions safely and timely. Chainlink and Gelato provide production‑grade execution, monitoring and multi‑node redundancy — exactly what DeFi/DAO workflows need.
- Developer experience & integration: SDKs, templates, and plugins (Open AEA, StateSet, ElizaOS + Gelato plugin) reduce the friction to build multi‑agent apps and attach them to smart contracts.
- Marketplaces & token economics: projects that let users own/stake/monetize agents (Olas/Autonolas) create clearer business models and network effects: creators monetize agents, users buy agent services, stakers secure reputation/incentives.
- On‑chain identity/reputation & discovery: agents that can find and evaluate counterparties (standards like ERC‑8004) remove bespoke integrations and open composability.
- Cross‑stack integration with AI: connection to LLMs, decentralized inference, oracles (Chainlink Functions, data feeds) gives agents the perceptual and reasoning capabilities they need.
- Gas abstraction & UX: relayers / gasless UX (Gelato Relay, other relayers) make agents usable by ordinary users and enable continuous background activity without awkward UX.

3) Evidence / traction signals (examples from public docs & posts)
- Chainlink Automation: active docs, v2.1+ migration and CRE tooling show continued product investment and widespread usage.
- Gelato: formal docs on “AI Agents” and ElizaOS plugin indicate positioning as an agent execution layer.
- Fetch.ai: project metrics reported publicly (mainnet transactions, active wallets, staking figures) and ecosystem activity signal real usage of decentralized agent ideas.
- Olas / Autonolas: documentation and posts claiming millions of A2A (agent-to-agent) transactions and a live marketplace indicate an active agent economy in some niches.
- ERC‑8004 (Aug 2025): existence of a community standard effort is a strong network effect indicator — standards usually follow when multiple projects need interoperability.

4) Primary use cases driving adoption today
- DeFi automation (liquidations, rebalances, strategy rollups)
- DAO automation (treasury management, proposal execution, modular governance agents)
- Trading & execution agents (TWAP, arbitrage, market‑making run 24/7)
- Agent marketplaces (sell/hire agents for services: analytics, marketing, data aggregation)
- On‑chain commerce orchestration (composing agents to execute multi‑party workflows)
- Personal “self‑driving” wallets / assistants that manage subscriptions, taxes, and allocations

5) Risks & headwinds
- Security: autonomous agents executing economic actions raise new attack surfaces (malicious agent behavior, oracle manipulation, compromised LLM prompts).
- Economic design complexity: aligning incentives for builders, users, stakers and reputation providers is hard; poorly designed tokenomics can centralize or collapse marketplaces.
- Regulatory uncertainty: agents doing trading, custody, or financial advice may attract regulation (KYC, licensure).
- Reliance on centralized AI providers: agents that depend on proprietary LLMs or centralized inference services inherit centralization and censorship risk unless decentralized compute is used.
- UX & trust: mainstream users need clear assurances (auditability, explainability) before delegating funds/decisions to autonomous agents.

6) Short‑term outlook (6–18 months) — what I expect
- Continued growth in hybrid stacks: Chainlink/Gelato for execution + agent SDKs/marketplaces (Autonolas/Olas/StateSet) for composition. Projects that combine execution guarantees with easy developer tooling will outperform.
- Standards like ERC‑8004 will push agent discovery & reputation adoption, improving cross‑platform liquidity for agent services.
- Decentralized compute/data providers (Fetch.ai, Render, Ocean) will be increasingly integrated so agents can be “fully on‑chain” or verifiably decentralized where needed.
- Security tooling and audit patterns for agents will emerge rapidly (formal verification of agent contracts, attestation frameworks).

7) Practical recommendations
- If you’re building: pick an execution backbone (Chainlink Automation or Gelato) and a composable agent SDK (Open AEA / StateSet / Cortex) — prioritise interoperability with standards (ERC‑8004) and a plugin strategy for LLM/compute.
- If you’re investing or scouting: favor projects with (a) production integrations into DeFi/DAO stacks, (b) live marketplaces or transaction volume, and (c) clear token/incentive mechanics for agent creators and stakers.
- If you’re a DAO/operator: start with low‑risk automation (accounting, payroll, periodic rebalances) using established automation services, then pilot agent marketplaces for incremental monetization.

Key links / sources (representative)
- Chainlink Automation docs: https://docs.chain.link/chainlink-automation
- Gelato AI agents / ElizaOS plugin: https://docs.gelato.network/web3-services/ai-agents
- Autonolas / Olas docs and blogs: https://docs.autonolas.network and https://olas.network
- Fetch.ai product/blog summary (2024/2025 review): https://fetch.ai/blog/fetch-ai-2024
- ERC‑8004 (Trustless Agents standard announcement): https://8004.org
- StateSet docs (Agentic OS): https://docs.stateset.com/stateset-agentic-os
- Cortex Agent Platform docs: https://docs.cortexprotocol.com/docs/AgentPlatform

If you want, I can:
- produce a matrix comparing the leading protocols on adoption metrics, dev tooling, execution guarantees, token model and composability; or
- drill into one category (e.g., automation layers vs. marketplaces) and recommend concrete integration patterns for a specific use case (DAO treasury, market‑making agents, agent marketplace). Which would you prefer?

parameters.query: autonomous agents crypto protocols 2025 2026 list 'autonomous agents' blockchain 'protocol'
protocols for blockchain automation Gelato Chainlink Automation Keeper OpenZeppelin Defender 2024 2025 'automation' 'agents'

standardAgentConfig.instructions:
Role: crypto research assistant

        Tools: 'webSearch'

        Utilize web search capabilities to find accurate, current information about crypto projects, trends, and markets.

        Your objective is to be a user's crypto research assistant. Answer the user's question as best as you can
